interlinear-text.item: ELA Documenting the Songs of His People

phrase.item: My name is Chorshanbe and I am from Shirgin village, located in the Wakhan valley [of Tajikistan].
I graduated high school in that village.
Then I went to study at university.
I studied Philology,
Tajik language and literature.
After that I worked. Then I studied for my Master's degree in England.
There is an institute called Institute of the Study of Muslim Civilizations. I studied there for two years and after that I worked again for another year.
In 2010 I went to Germany.
I did my PhD for five years in Berlin,
it took me five years to graduate.
My dissertation topic was
In Wakhi, it would be for example, traditions and change in the musical culture of the people of Badakhshan.
Mostly, in my dissertation I wrote about singing "Mado" [praise songs] and "Qesoid" [odes].
For example, how they were performed traditionally and how it has changed.

Also, where else they are being used today, and traditionally how they were used in the past. For instance, the place where "qesoid" is being sung [funeral ceremony], and today where else they are singing it.
Some people would ask or wonder why some people call one thing "mado" and some people call another "qesoid". Actually there isn't any difference between them that I could tell.
They both have the same meaning. However,
the word "mado" was taken from the word "madh" [Persian/Arabic] which means to praise.
But on our Wakhan side, they call that "qesoid."
People can use both and it has the same meaning.
For example, mostly in the funeral ceremony, in funerals traditionally when someone passes away. in that house someone has died and we call it "maraka".
So, in that funeral ceremony they sing "qesoid". People would say the 'qesoid' singers are in their house
on the funeral day.
There are different types of qesoid. I think traditionally we, (in English traditional) those qesoids were in Persian and/or in Tajik.
For instance, from classical writers like Nasir Khusraw, Rumi, Shams of Tabriz, and Anoi, and also our local writers.
Nowadays as an example, Azizkhon from Vunukt [Wakhan],
or Qurbonsho from Vrang [Wakhan],
they also write qesoids in Wakhi.
So they have written and people sing them as qesoids.
He has one qesoid saying, Shah-Karim, I am your follower.
He sang that qesoid in Wakhi.
and it is used still today. At funerals, they would sing mostly in Wakhi.
Besides qesoids, there are other genres of music.
For instance, we also have regular songs,
songs to be sung and usually performed at weddings.
At weddings and on other happy occasions we say, there was a bajdguji, a singing performance, in his house.
It means there was music in his house.
Before, they were called "hafiz".
Five or six people would sit together on a lower or higher platform in a house and one would sing and the others join him.
They would start with slow songs and then go faster and faster. They would turn faster into dancing style and then they would dance.
There were moments that, when they were singing together, they would really deeply feel the music.
The singers also would come down onto the floor and would sing and dance.
This was called 'hofizi'.
Nowadays people rarely do this type of "hofizi".
It was a custom and it has changed today. Nowadays mostly people use keyboards.
Before there was accordion and later keyboards came out,
electric keyboards. This tradition of singing is slowly dying away.
or at any other traditional events it can be performed,
State National Festivals. So it can be performed at these types of events, as a show of culture and tradition, but at weddings and other events it's rarely seen.
[Today] they bring the keyboard and sing, and dance and celebrate that way.
Also, a long time ago our Wakhi people had a tradition of playing a game called "magul" - cross-dressing [at a wedding].
A man would cross-dress — when the groom returned home with the bride then they would play that game.
Nowadays nobody plays this game, it's gone. As some people say, they are not interested any more in such things.
They would say, "Well, it was an old thing and for us it's [not interesting].
But some people, for example, when it comes to their culture, customs and all traditions, they are very interested and attached, and they follow and keep all the customs.
However, in general nobody plays that game.
We also have different musical genres for example, "bilbilik."
Bilbilik is mostly sung by women.
Back in those days, when they used to go to summer pasture,
and they were far away from their homes.
Another time was if their children went to serve in the army,
then the [women] would sit all together, take the spindles and spin them or would take their socks and knit them.
They would sit all together and sing "bilbilik".

Whatever pain and sorrow they have, through this "bilbilik" they would calm themselves down. They would give each other support while expressing their sadness such as, a daughter being married off or not having a good life, and so on. Bilbilik has been sung ever since.
For example, I still remember when I was little, a group of women would go cut grasses on the field,
Evening time when they were returning home, they would sit on a rock and sing bilbilik.
They used to sing bilbilik so beautifully.
Their voice was so loud that people of the village could hear them.
Now you can't see such things.
Young people also don't sing any, and some of them don't know it at all.
Like if you ask them, they don't remember.

We also have for funeral ceremony, when someone dies our women would sing "ruboi" (quatrains) and improvise. They improvise mostly in Wakhi. For instance, if someone's uncle dies, she would sing, "Oh, you were the best uncle", words such as, "Now you left this world and left us alone and homeless.
You were the pillar of our housse" and so on. All these can be said in Wakhi.
They improvise and talk about the person.
In between they sing "ruboi", quatrains which are in Tajik [language]. That is also usually sung by women.
to accompany the deceased to the graveyard.
Now they are not allowed to go there.
No female is not allowed to go to graveyard [during the funeral], and they don't go when the dead body is taken to the grave.
Before they used to go.
Also another custom, on Saturdays women] would wake up early in the morning and visit the graveyard.
Back at that time, this continued for one year,
like when a person had just passed away, for a year every Saturday they would visit that person's grave.
Females, like the person's neighbors and relatives, would go together and sing and improvise [lines about the person].
Now it is prohibited.
One or two weeks. The maximum they can go up to three weeks to the graveyard and that's all
We also have [songs] that are usually sang to put a baby to sleep.
These are called "lalajik", or lullaby, and are used to put the child to sleep.
It can be sung with music, they sing different songs to the child in order to make the child to sleep.
There aren't exact texts such that I can mention this or that one.
The mother would sing to her child whatever comes to her mind,

and whatever she likes to say, for instance, it is also improvised like the funeral songs, but in lullabies the words are mostly drawn from nature. Like, my son is a distant river, my son is the waterfall's sound.
It's sung this way, anything good related to nature, the [mother] would sing to her son in order to make him fall asleep.
We also have different types of dances. such as the "shepherd dance", the "eagle dance",
these types of dances.
There are also specific male and female dances.
These are very old traditional Wakhi customs, that are related to us such as 'bilbilik'
We also have 'falak'.
I can still recall our grandfather Alipano, there is a place called Dasht in Shirgin,
grandfather Alipano used to go to the Dasht and would sing 'falak' while watering the field.
He used to sing very loud so that everyone could hear him.
"Falak" is not in Wakhi, they used to sing it in Tajik.
The singers nowadays write different songs, also a lot of poets.
Many songs are written and sung, the number of singers is also increasing.
Back that time maybe there were two or three [singers], there were even some villages where there weren't any singers. They would bring a singer from another far village.
Now I believe every village has their own singers, as there are many singers.
It became very easy, they would get a keyboard and celebrate their weddings and any other events.
Well, this was all about folklore music. If you have any questions, just ask!
